conversation.content: [nervously] Listen, I know this looks strange, me being here at two in the morning with a crowbar, but I can explain everything if you'll just give me a minute before calling the cops.

[calmly] You're about thirty seconds too late for that threat to work—I already called them when I saw your truck pull up. [pause] Though I'm curious what explanation you think justifies breaking into my warehouse.

Your warehouse? This place has been abandoned for three years, owned by some shell company in Delaware that never responded to any inquiries. [sighs] I had an arrangement with the previous management.

Shell company went bankrupt last month, and I picked this place up at auction for basically nothing. [curious] What kind of arrangement involves crowbars and midnight visits to supposedly abandoned buildings?

[hesitantly] I restore vintage motorcycles, and the previous owner let me store some rare parts here while I was between shops. [clearing throat] The crowbar was just to pry open the storage unit I've been renting.
[skeptical] Vintage motorcycles. Right. And I suppose those shipping containers behind the false wall in Section C are full of carburetors and chrome bumpers?

[quietly] You found those already? Most people don't notice that wall for months. [exhales] Look, whatever you think is in those containers, you're probably wrong, and definitely better off not knowing.

[firmly] I spent fifteen years as a customs inspector before I retired early and started buying distressed properties. [chuckles] I know contraband architecture when I see it, and frankly, your setup here is impressive.

[surprised] Customs inspector? Christ, of all the people to buy this place. [bitter] I suppose you're going to want to make some kind of citizen's arrest, collect a reward from whoever's looking for what's in there?

[warmly] I retired because I got tired of ruining people's lives over arbitrary borders and regulations that change with every election. [pause] Whatever's in those containers has been here three years without hurting anyone, hasn't it?

[confused] Are you saying you're willing to just let me take my property and leave? [anxiously] Because that sounds like either a trap or the kind of generosity that comes with a very expensive price tag attached.

[modest] No trap, no price tag, just a practical solution to both our problems—you need your items gone, and I need plausible deniability when I renovate this place. [sincerely] But there's one condition.
[resigned] Here it comes. You want a cut, information about my suppliers, maybe a new motorcycle for your retirement garage? [sighs] Everyone wants something in this business.
[gently] I want you to teach me about those vintage motorcycles you mentioned—the lie was good because it had truth in it. [chuckles] I saw the '67 Triumph in your truck, restored beautifully.
[stunned] You want motorcycle lessons? That's it? [laughs] You're either the strangest ex-customs officer I've ever met, or the best liar, and honestly, I'm not sure which possibility scares me more.

[friendly] Maybe both, maybe neither—retirement gives you perspective on what actually matters in life. [warmly] So, do we have a deal? You clear out your containers this week, and Saturday mornings you teach me about British racing bikes?

[relieved] Saturday mornings for motorcycle lessons in exchange for my freedom and my cargo. [exhales] You know what? After three years of looking over my shoulder, this might be the most honest deal I've ever made.
Good.

[warmly] I should probably cancel that police call I lied about earlier—never actually made it, seemed unnecessary for a midnight property inspection. [pause] Your truck's transmission sounds rough, by the way, might want to check that.

[laughing] A smuggler giving me mechanical advice after I just gave them a free pass on three containers of contraband. [sighs] This is definitely the strangest Tuesday night I've had since retirement.

scenario: A smuggler arrives at a remote warehouse to retrieve hidden contraband, only to discover the property has just been sold to a new owner who's conducting a midnight inspection.
